Fig. 2 Fig. 3 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the meso/macroporous supports (up) and corresponding pore size distribution curves; BJH analysis of adsorption data (down). The isotherms and pore size distribution curve of SBA-15 correspond to the right Y axis scale. Graphical abstract The valorization of various types of low-quality vegetable oils with relatively high content of free fatty acids (FFA) is a research field of increased interest. The esterification of oleic acid, a highly abundant FFA in waste oils, with trimethylolpropane (TMP) towards the production of the corresponding triesters, which can be used in lubricants or hydraulic fluids, was studied in this work. The catalysts tested were various meso/macroporous oxides, such as ZrO2, 3.5%SiO2-ZrO2, SiO2-Al2O3, SBA-15 and Al-SBA-15 with varying textural and acidic properties and the corresponding supported heteropoly acid catalysts, prepared by the use of phosphotungstic (H3PW12O40) and tungstosilicic (H4SiW12O40) acids. The catalysts were characterized by ICP-AES, XRD, FT-IR, N2 porosimetry and FT-IR coupled with pyridine adsorption. The main product at 200°C and after 6h of reaction was the triester (TE) of oleic acid with selectivity values ranging from 85% to 99% at conversion degrees of 82% to 96%. The two aluminosilicate catalysts that combine Brønsted and Lewis acidity (i.e. SiO2-Al2O3 and Al-SBA-15) showed slightly higher yields of triester (∼83%) compared to the rest oxides (∼78%), while the Brønsted acidity induced by the two heteropoly acids, especially by PW, provided very high reactivity and selectivity towards triesters, irrespective of the type of support used, reaching triester yield values of 95% (96.2% conversion, 98.7% selectivity) with the 20%PW/ZrO2 catalyst. The most stable catalysts against leaching of heteropoly acids were those supported on 3.5%SiO2-ZrO2 and SiO2-Al2O3. Keywords Free fatty acids Esterification Polyols BioLubricants Heteropoly acids and polyoxometalates (POM) Meso/macroporous oxides and aluminosilicates 1 Introduction In the last decades, there is a great concern about the depletion of natural resources and the need for an alternative and sustainable way to produce energy, chemicals and materials is increasing. A possible solution comes from the valorization of biomass-derived wastes such as lignocellulosic biomass, low quality vegetable oils and animal fats. trans-esterification of triglycerides, derived from high quality edible vegetable oils, is a well-known process for the production of biodiesel [1,2]. However, in the last two decades the research and development interest has focused on utilization of low quality waste cooking oils or animal fats, in order to avoid the “food vs. fuel” dilemma and at the same time to reduce disposal costs and make value out of waste. The low quality vegetable oils contain a high amount of free fatty acids (FFA), which, in biodiesel production, leads to soap formation, affecting the ester yield and glyceride conversion. In this case, a pre-treatment step via esterification of free fatty acids is required. The esterification of FFA with MeOH in the presence of H2SO4 can lead to a mixture of methylesters and triglycerides, which then can be converted to biodiesel through trans-esterification of triglycerides with methanol and KOH or NaOH [2]. FFA can also be converted to diesel − range hydrocarbons (C15- C19) via hydro-treatment with various supported metal catalysts [3]. The esterification of free fatty acids with different polyols (i.e. trimethylolpropane etc.) towards lubricants and hydraulic liquids is another important alternative for the valorization of waste vegetable oils with high content of FFA [4–6]. Indeed, the produced triesters may have improved pour point (PP), thermal and oxidative stability properties but could also exhibit negative traits such as inferior viscosity, viscosity index (VI), and biodegradability [7]. The possible valorization routes of FFA are summarized in Fig. 1 . Fig. 1 Homogeneous acid catalysis has been used in several studies for the esterification of free fatty acids [8–12]. However, it has several disadvantages if applied to industrial processes: wasting large amounts of catalysts, corrosion of reactors, water pollution by acidic wastewater and difficulty of catalyst recovery [13]. Heterogeneous catalysis with the use of acidic solids instead of mineral acids can provide numerous advantages, such as easier catalyst separation and reuse, easier separation of products, energy savings and less environmental damage. In this respect different kind of solid catalysts have been studied in the last years particularly in the esterification with methanol for biodiesel production [14–16]. As far as the esterification of FFA with polyols is concerned, very few cases of heterogeneous systems are known, relying on the use of sulfated zirconia catalysts [17] and of amorphous mixed oxides such as SiO2-ZrO2 and SiO2-TiO2 [18]. The activity and selectivity of SiO2-ZrO2 and SiO2-TiO2 catalysts in the esterification of different FFAs with various polyols, i.e. trimethylolpropane, pentaerythrol and neopentyl glycol, was reported in the latter study. Polyoxometalates (POMs) are molecular metal oxides formed through condensation reactions of early transition metal-oxygen anions, with metals such as W, Mo, V, etc., in their highest oxidation rate [19,20]. They exhibit tunable acid/base and redox properties depending on their composition and can be used as catalysts either homogenously as soluble acids/salts or as supported heteropoly acids (HPA) in heterogeneous systems for a wide variety of reactions and processes, ranging from cellulose hydrolysis in water to photocatalytic oxidation of aromatic alcohols [21–27]. Esterification is one class of reactions where the supported heteropoly acids have found application due to their acidic properties [21,28–31]. For instance, Kulkarni et al. [32] used tungstophosphoric acid (H3PW12O40) impregnated on four different supports (hydrous zirconia, alumina, silica and activated carbon), to convert low quality canola oil containing 20% of free fatty acids to biodiesel (fatty acid methyl esters-FAME). The highest ester yield (77%) was achieved at 200°C by using hydrous zirconia as support. In a similar work, Sunita et al. [33] reported high yields of FAME in the transesterification reaction of sunflower oil with methanol at 200°C over zirconia supported H3PW12O40. Recently, Sheikh et al. [34] studied the esterification of oleic acid with ethanol by using H3PW12O40 supported on mesoporous titania-silica composite. The activity of these catalysts increased with increasing loading of polyoxometalate up to 20%, while higher amounts had a negative effect on the stability of the catalyst. In addition to esterification or transesterification of fatty acids, the reaction of acetic acid with alcohols over supported polyoxometalates has been also investigated [29]. In the present work, we investigated the activity and selectivity of a wide variety of metal oxides and of the corresponding supported polyoxometalate (POM) catalysts in the esterification of oleic acid with trimethylolpropane (TMP). Six different meso/macroporous oxides (ZrO2, SiO2-ZrO2, SiO2-Al2O3, SBA-15 and Al-SBA-15) with different textural and acidic properties were tested as catalysts, while the supported POM catalysts were prepared by the use of two types of heteropoly acids (H3PW12O40 and H4SiW12O40). Although the (trans)esterification of fatty acids with small mono-alcohols over supported heteropoly acids has been previously studied to some extent, there is a lack of reports on the activity of these catalysts in the esterification of fatty acids with poly-alcohols, such as trimethylolpropane, a substrate widely used for the production of lubricants because of the high thermal stability of the triesters obtained due to the absence of H atoms in β-position with respect to ester groups. The reactivity and selectivity of all the catalysts tested towards mono-, di- and triesters was correlated with the acidic and porosity characteristics and the successful grafting of the heteropoly acids in the case of POM-supported catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and preparation of meso/macroporous oxides Zirconium oxide (ZrO2) and its silica-doped analogue (3.5%SiO2-ZrO2) have been used after calcination of the corresponding hydroxides Zr(OH)4 and 3.5% SiO2-Zr(OH)4, that were received from MEL Chemicals. The calcination conditions were: 550○C for 2h in air flow (100 cc/min) at a heating rate of 2°C/min. A commercial γ-Al2O3 catalyst (Engelhard, Al-3992) and a laboratory synthesized [35] silica-alumina catalyst (SiO2-Al2O3) with Si/Al=35 were also used as catalysts and as supports of POMs. The high surface area mesoporous SBA-15 silica was synthesized according to previously reported methods [36–38]. Pluronic 123 (P123: EO20PO70EO20 with Mav=5800, BASF) which is a triblock copolymer of the poly(ethylene oxide) − poly(propylene oxide) − poly(ethylene oxide) type was used as the neutral mesostructure-directing agent. P123 was dissolved in aqueous 1M HCl solution at pH≤1, 40°C. Tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, Merck) was then added as the Si source and the solution was stirred for another 24h. The molar ratio of the synthesis mixture was 1 TEOS: 0.018 P123: 2.1 HCl: 115H2O. Aging of the resulting suspension was performed under static conditions at 100°C for 72h. The synthesis of mesoporous aluminosilicate Al-SBA-15 was similar to that of the siliceous SBA-15 except for the addition of sodium aluminate after TEOS [37]. The molar ratio of the synthesis mixture was 1 TEOS: 0.05Al: 0.018 P123: 0.10 HCl: 115H2O. The initially formed mixture was stirred overnight at 25°C (pH=2), and then heated to 40°C, leading to the gradual formation of a gel and finally of a white precipitate after ∼5h. This suspension was stirred for another 4h before adjusting the pH to 2.5 by NaOH aqueous solution (4M). The final suspension was aged at 100°C under static conditions for 24h. The as-synthesized samples were calcined at 500°C for 7h under air flow to remove the organic template. 2.2 Preparation of supported POM catalysts For the preparation of the POM supported catalysts materials, two hetepoly acids (HPA) with Keggin structure, i.e. phosphotungstic acid hydrate and tungstosilicic acid hydrate (Fig. 2 ), were used as received from Sigma Aldrich. The supported polyoxometalate catalysts investigated in this study were prepared by the incipient wetness method. According to this method, the polyoxometalate was dissolved in 0.1N hydrochloric acid (HCl) aqueous solution, which was then added to the porous support dropwise under constant mixing. The total volume of the added solution equaled the total pore volume of the support mass used. The content of POMs in the catalyst was kept constant and equal to 20wt.%. After the impregnation, all the catalysts were dried at 100°C overnight and then were calcined at 200°C for 4h under static air, for stabilization. Fig. 2 shows the chemical formula and structure of the heteropoly acids used to prepare the catalysts [39,40]. The catalytic materials were characterized for their chemical composition (ICP-AES), structure (XRD), porosity (N2 porosimetry) and acidic properties (FTIR/pyridine). 2.3 Catalyst characterization The chemical composition of the catalysts was determined by inductive coupled plasma − atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) using a Plasma 400 (Perkin Elmer) spectrometer equipped with a Cetac6000AT+ ultrasonic nebulizer. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was applied to determine the crystalline structure of the oxide supports and the ordering of the hexagonal mesophase of SBA-15 silica, using a Rigaku Rotaflex 200B diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα X-ray radiation and a curved crystal graphite monochromator operating at 45kV and 100mA; counts were accumulated in the range of 5–75° 2θ (for oxides) and 0.5–10° 2θ (for the mesoporous SBA-15 materials) every 0.02° (2θ) with counting time 2s per step. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption experiments were performed at −196°C to determine the specific surface area (multi-point BET method), total pore volume (at P/Po=0.99) and pore size distribution (BJH method using the adsorption data) of the catalysts, which were previously outgassed at 150°C − 250°C for 16h under 6.6×10−9 mbar vacuum using an Automatic Volumetric Sorption Analyzer (Autosorb-1MP, Quantachrome). FT-IR spectra of the parent heteropoly acids and oxide supports, as well as of the supported POM catalysts, were obtained on a FTIR Perkin-Elmer, model Spectrum 1, with a resolution of 4cm−1, using KBr diluted powdered samples that were pressed into thin pellets. The determination of the amount and strength of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of the meso/macroporous oxides and the supported POMs catalysts was performed by Fourier transform-infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy combined with in situ adsorption of pyridine. The FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 5700 FTIR spectrometer with a resolution of 4cm−1 using the OMNIC software and a specially designed heated, high-vacuum IR cell with calcium fluoride windows. Data processing was carried out by means of GRAMS software. All the samples were finely ground in a mortar and pressed into self-supported wafers (15mg/cm2). The wafers were outgassed at 450°C (oxide supports) and 250°C (POM supported catalysts in order to preserve the structure of POMs and avoid decomposition towards the respective mixed oxides) for 1h under vacuum 10−6 mbar, and the background spectrum was recorded at 150°C and 100°C, respectively. Adsorption/equilibration with pyridine vapours was then conducted at 150°C (oxide supports) or 100°C (supported POM catalysts) by adding pulses of pyridine for 1h at a total cell pressure of 1mbar. Spectra were recorded at 150°C (or 100°C) after equilibration with pyridine at that temperature to determine the total number of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. In addition, the strength of the acid sites was evaluated by recording the spectra after equilibrating the samples for 30min at higher temperatures, i.e. in the range of 250–450°C for oxide supports and 150–250°C for supported POM catalysts. The bands at 1545cm−1 (pyridinium ions) and 1450cm−1 (coordinated pyridine) were used to identify and quantify the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, respectively, by adopting the molar extinction coefficients provided by Emeis [41]. 2.4 Catalytic tests The catalytic esterification experiments were carried out in a glass reactor (flask) equipped with gas inlet, at 160°C and 200°C under N2 flow and stirring at 400rpm (external mass transfer limitations were absent as verified by varying the stirring speed from 350 to 600rpm). The experiments were performed within the time range of zero (as soon as reaction temperature was reached) to 6h, while samples were taken periodically for analysis. In a typical experiment, the oleic acid (10g), trimethylolpropane (TMP, 1.584g, molar ratio oleic acid: TMP=3:1) and 2.5wt.% (on oleic acid) catalyst were charged in the reactor. The reactor was heated in an oil bath (Silica Oil AP 100, Aldrich) and the temperature was controlled with a mercury thermometer. The water produced during the reaction was instantly removed by using a Liebig condenser. After reaction the liquid mixture was separated from the catalyst by simple centrifugation. The free fatty acid content of the liquid product and the% conversion was determined by titration. According to the method, the sample was dissolved in a mixture of 1:2 EtOH/diethylether and then titrated with 0.1N NaOH and phenolphthalein. The product distribution was determined by GC analysis (Agilent 7890N equipped with an AT-1 column, 12 m_0.32 mm_0.1mm). Before injection, the fatty acids and esters were derivatized by using N,O-bis(trimethylsilyl)trifluoroacetamide (BSTFA) and adding hexadecane as internal standard before GC analysis. The percent conversion of oleic acid was determined by the equation: % C o n v e r s i o n = A c ( s ) − A c ( f ) A c ( s ) · 100 In the above equation the subscript “(s)” refers to the starting acidity and “(f)” to the final acidity after reaction. The percent selectivity to the monoesters (ME), diesters (DE) and triesters (TE) of oleic acid with TMP was determined by the equations: % S e l e c t i v i t y M E = n M E n M E + 2 n D E + 3 n T E · 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y D E = 2 n D E n M E + 2 n D E + 3 n T E · 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y T E = 3 n T E n M E + 2 n D E + 3 n T E · 100 Where n stands for moles of the respective compound. The yield of the esters was determined by the equation (i.e. for the triesters): % Y i e l d T E = % S e l e c t i v i t y T E × % C o n v e r s i o n 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical characteristics of meso/macroporous oxides and POM supported catalysts The porosity characteristics of the meso/macroporous oxides and of the POM supported catalysts, are given in Table 1 and the respective N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms are shown in Figs. 3 and 4 , as well as in Figure S-1 (Supporting Information). The commercial γ-Al2O3 and silica-alumina (SiO2-Al2O3) oxides exhibit isotherms of similar shape (Fig. 3) which are characteristic of mesoporous materials. The adsorption isotherms of both oxides are of IV type and the desorption isotherm of γ-Al2O3 is type H1 and of SiO2-Al2O3 is type H2 (H1 refers to pores with relatively narrow pore size distribution while H2 may indicate enhanced heterogeneity in pore size/shape and/or ink-bottle type pores), according to the IUPAC classification [42,43]. The surface area of γ-Al2O3 is 195m2/g and that of SiO2-Al2O3 is 470m2/g. The pore size distribution curves (Fig. 3) and the respective data in Table 1, show that the average mesopore size (diameter) of γ-Al2O3 is ∼13nm and of SiO2-Al2O3 is 6nm. The adsorption isotherm of SBA-15 (as well as of Al-SBA-15, not shown for brevity) is typical of these high surface area silicas with 1D-tubular pore channels stacked in a 2-D hexagonal arrangement. A steep nitrogen uptake at P/Po∼0.7 indicate the narrow pore size distribution of SBA-15, as is also verified by the respective curve in Fig. 3, the average pore diameter being∼8nm (Table 1). The surface area of SBA-15 and Al-SBA-15 is 1003 and 825m2/g, respectively. The ZrO2 support has relatively low surface area (∼90m2/g) exhibiting a meso/macroporous structure with a very broad pore size distribution. Addition of a small amount (3.5%) of SiO2 in ZrO2 results in substantial surface area increase (from 90 to 243m2/g) as well as in different pore morphology, as the 3%SiO2-ZrO2 material exhibits a mesoporous structure with relative narrow pore size distribution and average diameter of 3.3nm (Fig. 3 and Table 1). The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and the BJH pore size distribution curves of representative supported POM catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 and Figure S-1. It can be clearly seen that the shape of the isotherms is similar to those of the oxide supports, thus indicating minimum changes in the porous structure upon grafting of the two polyoxometalates. However, the surface area and pore volume of the catalysts are reduced by up to ca. 50%, depending on the type of support, due to partial pore blockage and coverage of their surface by the POMs (Table 1). The highest reduction was observed for the SiW/SiO2-ZrO2 supported catalyst, which showed a 54% and 51% decrease of surface area and total pore volume, respectively. The kinetic diameter of both hetepoly anions is ∼1.3nm, as calculated from crystallographic data of known compounds containing these anions, using the software Mercury from CCDC. Thus, the higher reduction of surface area and pore volume (∼40-50%) observed for 3.5% SiO2-ZrO2 can be attributed to its relatively small average pore diameter (3.3nm) as well as its low surface area and pore volume compared to the rest of the oxides. The average mesopore size was not significantly decreased, not more than 5%, thus further verifying the minimum destruction of the porous structures of the supports. Furthermore, there was no significant differentiation in the effect of the POM type on the porous characteristics of the respective catalysts, as can be seen from the N2 isotherms and pore size distribution curves of SiW and PW/ZrO2, as well as SiW and PW/3.5%SiO2-ZrO2 (Figure S-1). The retention of the structure of the two heteropoly acids (HPA) supported on the meso/macroporous oxides was evaluated by FTIR experiments. The PW12O40 3− and SiW12O40 3− Keggin anions structure consists of PO4 and SiO4 tetrahedra respectively that are surrounded by four W3O13 units formed by edge sharing octahedra. These units are bonded to each other by corner-sharing oxygen atoms. This structure has four types of oxygen atoms, being responsible for the fingerprint bands of the H3PW12O40 and H4SiW12O43 Keggin heteropoly acids (ca. 1200 − 700cm−1). The infrared spectra of pure H3PW12O40 and H4SiW12O40 are shown in Figs. 5 and 6 , respectively. The characteristic bands of H3PW12O40 at 805, 894, 984 and 1081cm−1 (Fig. 5) are attributed to ν as (W − Oc − W), ν as (W − Ob − W), ν as (W − Od) and ν as (P − Oa) respectively, where a, b, c, and d stand for different types of oxygen atoms in the Keggin structure [44–46]. Similarly, the characteristic bands of H4SiW12O40 at 787, 879, 926 and 980cm−1 (Fig. 6 ) are attributed to ν as (W − Oc − W), ν as (W − Ob − W), ν as (Si − Oa) and ν as (W − Od) respectively [47]. The presence of these bands in the spectra of the supported POM catalysts, i.e. PW/ZrO2 (Fig. 5) and SiW/3.5%SiO2/ZrO2 (Fig. 6), verified that the HPA Keggin structure has been preserved. Actually, the POM catalysts supported on ZrO2 and 3.5%SiO2-ZrO2 were the ones with the most clearly observed characteristic bands of HPAs, compared to the catalysts supported on SBA-15, Al-SBA-15, SiO2-Al2O3 and particularly on γ-Al2O3 where the bands due to POM could hardly be identified. The XRD patterns of the two POMs and of representative supported catalysts are shown in Figure S-2 (Supporting Information). The absence of clearly defined high intensity peaks owing to the crystalline POM structure in the respective catalysts verify the high dispersion of the heteropoly acids on the various meso/macroporous oxides. However, the relatively broad peaks at about 6.5-7.5° 2θ may be due to the presence of the POM phases, as these peaks are clearly absent from the patterns of the bare oxide supports. The amount of acid sites and their distribution amongst Brønsted and Lewis sites was determined by the FT-IR/pyridine adsorption measurements and the respective data is shown in Table 1. Representative FT-IR spectra of the meso/macroporous oxides and the POM supported catalysts with sorbed pyridine are shown in Fig. 7 . As described also in the experimental section, the band at 1450cm−1 is assigned to coordinated pyridine on Lewis acid sites whereas the band at 1545cm−1 is attributed to the pyridinium ion on Brønsted acid sites. It can be clearly seen that γ-Al2O3, ZrO2, and SiO2-ZrO2 have only Lewis acid sites (Fig. 7a and Table 1), SiO2-Al2O3 and Al-SBA-15 have both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, while the siliceous SBA-15 has negligible acidity (Fig. 7b and Table 1). After supporting of the two polyoxometalates, the Brønsted acidity of the various oxides increased significantly, except in the case of γ-Al2O3, due to a not very successful grafting of POMs on this oxide, as explained above. No significant variation is observed between the effect of phosphotungstic and tungstosilicic acids, with the latter inducing slightly higher Brønsted acidity than the former in the ZrO2 based catalysts. This can be clearly seen in the FTIR-pyridine spectra of the oxides and supported POM catalysts in Figure S-3 (Supporting Information), where the spectrum of each oxide support is presented in comparison to those of the corresponding SiW and PW supported catalysts. The Lewis acid sites are more or less the same with those of the parent oxides (with small increase or decrease), except in the case of the POM catalysts supported on ZrO2 and 3.5%SiO2/ZrO2 where the Lewis acid sites are substantially less compared to those of the parent oxides. This can be attributed to the formation of Zr-O-W bonds upon grafting of the polyoxometalates, thus masking the Lewis acidity offered by Zr. 3.2 Catalytic results The various acidic mixed oxides and the supported POM catalysts were evaluated in the reaction shown in Fig. 8 , i.e. the esterification of oleic acid with trimethylolpropane (TMP). According to the scheme, the esterification of oleic acid with trimethylolpropane (TMP) over acidic catalysts leads to the formation of polyesters of TMP: monoesters, diesters and triesters. During the reaction, water is also produced and it must be removed because its accumulation inhibits the esterification of FFA [48]. Activity screening tests were initially performed in the absence of catalyst in order to optimize the reaction conditions and actually after 6h at 200°C the reaction reached 85% conversion (with selectivity to TE ∼88%, to DE ∼11% and to ME ∼0.5%). Similar screening tests with time were conducted for the various mixed oxides and the supported POM catalysts (Fig. 9 ). As it can be seen in Fig. 9(a), there is no significant effect of the various mixed oxides in the conversion activity for longer reaction times. However, higher conversion (by up to 20%) can be observed at zero time (i.e. after 20min of heat-up time that is required for the system to reach 200°C) for all the mixed oxides, with γ-Al2O3 and Al-SBA-15 being the more active ones. The supported POM catalysts (20wt.% POM) induced similar increase of conversion compared to the non-catalytic reaction at zero time, while at longer reaction times of 1–6h, a much lower increase was observed, as can be seen in Fig. 9(b) and (c). The highest conversion (96%) was achieved by PW/ZrO2 after 6h. The SiW/SBA-15 catalyst appeared to be very active, even at low reaction times, including zero time, but as this catalyst showed relatively high degree of W leaching (discussed below), part of its reactivity could be attributed to homogeneously catalyzed reaction. In order to further study and elucidate the catalytic effect on conversion, tests at lower temperature (i.e. 160°C) and shorter reaction times (i.e. <2h) were also performed with two representative catalysts, i.e. 20%PW/ZrO2 and 20%PW/3.5%SiO2-ZrO2, as well as in the absence (non-catalytic) of any catalyst. It can be clearly seen from the data in Fig. 10 , that the presence of the catalysts does not induce any significant effect on conversion over the whole time range, compared to the non-catalytic reaction, in accordance with the results at 200°C. On the other hand, a significant effect of time at 160°C was observed in the selectivity towards the three esters, i.e. mono-, di- and triesters, as can be seen in the data of Fig. 11 . At zero time, both the above catalysts showed high selectivity towards monoesters (72–76%), the rest being diesters with no formation of triesters. As similar selectivity profile was observed for the non-catalytic test, the catalytic effect at zero time was again negligible. However, after 2h of reaction there was a substantial decrease of monoesters with both catalysts (<10% selectivity) giving rise to diester (55–64%) and most importantly to triesters selectivity (25–43%). The respective selectivity values for the non-catalytic run were 63% and 12%, thus showing a clear enhancement in the production of triesters by the presence of the catalysts. After 6h of reaction, this catalytic effect remained, with the two catalysts reaching 60%-69% selectivity to triesters and <1% selectivity to monoesters, while the respective values under non-catalytic conditions were 39% and 6%. In addition, the diesters remained higher in the non-catalytic run (54%) compared to the two catalysts (30–40%). It is thus clear, that the presence of the supported POM catalysts have a profound positive effect on triesters selectivity, compared to the non-catalytic system, at the relatively low temperature of 160°C. As a general trend however, it can be suggested that the conversion and triesters selectivity increase constantly with time (from 0 to 6h), the selectivity to monoesters decreases monotonically (especially from time zero to 2h), while the selectivity to diesters shows a maximum at intermediate reaction times of ca. 2–4h. The selectivity towards triesters in the esterification of oleic acid with polyalcohols is very important as they are necessary for providing high quality lubricants with high specific viscosity and viscosity index. Thus, the selectivity to mono-, di- and triesters of oleic acid with TMP for the various oxides and the respective supported POM catalysts, at the higher temperature of 200°C were also determined, in an effort to increase further the tri-esters selectivity. The respective data are shown in Fig. 12 (and Table S-1 in Supporting Information). As can be clearly seen, triesters were the main products with selectivity values ranging from 85% to 99%. Considering the high conversion degrees, these selectivity values corresponded to also very high yields of triesters, ranging from 77% to 95%, as can be seen in Table S-1. Amongst the various acidic metal oxides, those containing substantial amount of (only) Lewis acidity (i.e. γ-Al2O3, ZrO2 and SiO2-ZrO2) provided slightly lower selectivity to triesters (86%-90%, corresponding to yield of 77%–78%) compared to SiO2-Al2O3 and Al-SBA-15 (90%–93%, yield 83%) which comprise both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites (Table 1). On the other hand, the former provided slightly enhanced selectivity towards diesters (10%–13.5%), with the monoesters being always very low (<1% selectivity). This behavior is however different from the performance of SiO2-ZrO2 catalysts which contain relatively low amount of ZrO2 (i.e. 3–5%, the rest being SiO2) [18], in contrast to the catalysts of the present study that contain mainly ZrO2 (3.5% SiO2). In the case of the former (low-ZrO2) catalysts, an exceptionally high selectivity and yield (≥95%) of triesters was observed. This slight change/improvement of performance could be attributed to the relatively low/tuned amount of Lewis acid sites present in the low-ZrO2 catalysts compared to the enhanced Lewis acidity of the high-ZrO2 catalyst of the present work. With regard to the supported POM catalysts, those with PW exhibited exceptionally high selectivity to triesters (i.e. >98.5%) while those with SiW showed 90% − 99% selectivity depending on the support oxide. The corresponding values of triesters yield with all the supported POM catalysts were in the range of 77% to 95% (Table S-1, Supporting Information and Fig. 12). Based on the above results, it can be suggested that the Brønsted acidity offered by the two heteropoly acids, especially by PW, provides catalyst with high reactivity and selectivity towards triesters, irrespective of the type of support used. One of the usual problems encountered in the use of supported POM catalysts, is the leaching of heteropolyacids in the reaction medium [31]. Indeed, in the case of the catalysts supported on SBA-15 silica, about 30% of tungsten (W) was leached to the liquid medium after 6h of reaction at 200°C. The most stable catalysts were those supported on SiO2-ZrO2 and SiO2-Al2O3 with less than 10% W leaching. A second round of catalytic testing with the 20%SiW/3.5%SiO2-ZrO2 recovered catalyst (after washing and drying) provided similar yield to triesters (i.e. 81% versus 84% in the first round). Thus, although phosphotungstic (PW) and tungstosilicic (SiW), and perhaps other heteropoly acids, have the potential to provide highly efficient esterification catalysts, with yields of triesters reaching as high as 95%, further improvements are still required in terms of stability of the supported POM catalysts. 4 Conclusions The loading of two heteropoly acids, i.e. phosphotungstic (H3PW12O40) and tungstosilicic (H4SiW12O40) acids, on various meso/macroporous oxides (i.e. ZrO2, SiO2-ZrO2, SiO2-Al2O3, SBA-15 and Al-SBA-15), at 20wt.%, had no effect on the pore structure of the supports. The decreased surface area (by up to ca. 50%) was attributed only to pore blocking and coverage of the pore surface to different extent depending on the type of support. The structure of the two polyoxometalates was retained intact on all supported catalysts, and especially on ZrO2 and 3.5%SiO2-ZrO2, with the exception of γ-Al2O3 where the characteristic IR bands of POMs could be hardly identified. Furthermore, the high dispersion of POMs on the supports was verified by the absence of any distinct peaks attributed to bulk crystalline phases, as revealed by XRD measurements. The two POMs increased the Brønsted acidity of the various oxides significantly, except in the case of γ-Al2O3, due to a not very successful grafting of POMs on this oxide; tungstosilicic induced slightly higher Brønsted acidity compared to phosphotungstic acid, only in the case of ZrO2 based catalysts. Both the parent meso/macroporous oxides as well as the supported POM catalysts induced a 5–10% higher conversion of oleic acid in esterification with trimethylolpropane (TMP), compared to the already high-optimized conversion of 85% of the non-catalytic system, achieved at 200°C after 6h of reaction. Triesters were the main products with selectivity values ranging from 85% to 99%. With regard to the catalytic effect, the oxides having only Lewis acidity (i.e. γ-Al2O3, ZrO2 and 3.5%SiO2/ZrO2) were slightly less selective towards triesters, in favor of the diesters, compared to SiO2-Al2O3 and Al-SBA-15 which contained both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. The Brønsted acidity offered by the two heteropoly acids, especially by PW, induced high reactivity and selectivity towards triesters, irrespective of the type of support used, reaching triester yield values of 95% (96.2% conversion, 98.7% selectivity) with 20%PW/ZrO2 catalyst. The experiments performed at lower temperature (160°C) and shorter reaction times (<2h) with the 20%PW/ZrO2 and 20%PW/3.5%SiO2-ZrO2 catalysts, mainly for investigating further the catalytic effect on conversion and selectivity, showed that the presence of supported POM catalysts favor the formation of triesters compared to the non-catalytic runs, leading at the same time to the production of less diesters and negligible monoesters. Leaching of POMs remains an issue, with the most stable catalysts in this work being those supported on 3.5%SiO2-ZrO2 and SiO2-Al2O3. coredata.dc:description: The valorization of various types of low-quality vegetable oils with relatively high content of free fatty acids (FFA) is a research field of increased interest. The esterification of oleic acid, a highly abundant FFA in waste oils, with trimethylolpropane (TMP) towards the production of the corresponding triesters, which can be used in lubricants or hydraulic fluids, was studied in this work. The catalysts tested were various meso/macroporous oxides, such as ZrO2, 3.5%SiO2-ZrO2, SiO2-Al2O3, SBA-15 and Al-SBA-15 with varying textural and acidic properties and the corresponding supported heteropoly acid catalysts, prepared by the use of phosphotungstic (H3PW12O40) and tungstosilicic (H4SiW12O40) acids. The catalysts were characterized by ICP-AES, XRD, FT-IR, N2 porosimetry and FT-IR coupled with pyridine adsorption. The main product at 200°C and after 6h of reaction was the triester (TE) of oleic acid with selectivity values ranging from 85% to 99% at conversion degrees of 82% to 96%. The two aluminosilicate catalysts that combine Brønsted and Lewis acidity (i.e. SiO2-Al2O3 and Al-SBA-15) showed slightly higher yields of triester (∼83%) compared to the rest oxides (∼78%), while the Brønsted acidity induced by the two heteropoly acids, especially by PW, provided very high reactivity and selectivity towards triesters, irrespective of the type of support used, reaching triester yield values of 95% (96.2% conversion, 98.7% selectivity) with the 20%PW/ZrO2 catalyst. The most stable catalysts against leaching of heteropoly acids were those supported on 3.5%SiO2-ZrO2 and SiO2-Al2O3.
coredata.dc:title: Esterification of free fatty acids using acidic metal oxides and supported polyoxometalate (POM) catalysts
